content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, difficulty level is appropriate.

And, for what is worth, the "Note" section and its 5 entries should probably be all capitalized for consistency (instead of 2/5 as of now). 

Same for the Input (lacking a final dot at Line 2) / Output sections.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Re-approving. My old solution still passes everything. 

I would add the list length in the input (and change the stub to a list of ints) to help with the parsing in C and the likes, but I'm fine too with OP's stance that it is redundant.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it is a fun puzzle

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
incredible

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Original and interesting, functional tests and validators and of suitable difficulty :thumbsup:

Alright, I finally finished it and here's the promised upvote :thumbsup:

One thing, I basically adapted the algorithm of the wiki and currently, after fixing the root, if you don't sort the children nodes you can pass every validator (although not every test, you fail test 4 and 7), so you could technically have 100% in the puzzle while not passing the tests which imo is an issue. So I'll suggest to add a validator (could just be a slight variation of either test 4 or 7 where you have to do the sorting). For example in 4, if I don't sort I will output:
(1 (3) (2 (5) (4 (7) (6 (9) (8 (10) (11))))))
yet the correct answer is:
(1 (2 (4 (6 (8 (10) (11)) (9)) (7)) (5)) (3))

tldr:
 "2. same level nodes follows the order from small to large." is not actually tested in the validators

If you find time to fix it I'll gladly approve the puzzle.
Update: use different node as root to present the tree
Maybe I'm not understanding the problem, but shouldn't (1 (5 (2) (7 (6 (3) (4))))) yield 5 6 6 7 5 as its Prüfer sequence? (we trim 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 6 -> 7). I'm talking about validator 1.

Goal section
* "2 2 1 3 3", "2", "2 2", "(1 (2 (4) (5)) (3 (6) (7)))", etc may be formatted as <<bold>> as they are not really [[variables]].
* Please add "list" in front of "format for a tree", as you mention the term "list format" in Output section, which is not defined anywhere else.
* I think you have to specify that a list is represented by its nodes/elements enclosed within brackets.
* Is there a better way to present the example tree visually? I can't see how the nodes are connected to each other. And maybe it'll help formatting it as `monospace`.

Input section
* [[N]] in Constraints section is not defined anywhere. Also I think it is better to provide the integers as inputs directly instead of a string in the stub generator, so I would suggest to add [[N]] as an input (number of nodes I think?).

Constraint section
* "natural numbers" instead of "nature numbers".
* 1 is not a [[variable]].
* [[N]] should be defined here, in case [[N]] is not added as an input per my comment above.

Stub generator
* If [[N]] is added as an input, this section needs to be updated too. Also as a consequence "loopline" should be used to provide the prufer code as individual integers.

Thanks.

thanks!
N is not equal to the total number of nodes. I prefer to keep it simple, as the length of the list is a redundant information.

after trim of 2, 1 become one of the leaf.
so trim 2 1 3 4 5 (my mistake, should be 1 2 3 4 5, 1 is an ending point from beginning)

Thanks!
I tried my solution without sorting, it even cannot pass test 1 and validator 1...Maybe my solution is not lucky enough :)
Anyway, I add a last case with some permutations, hope that is good enough for checking the sorting.
thanks a lot!
Nice, now I can't pass validator 8 without sorting. All good.
i modify the wording of Step 1, i guess could be better to avoid "leaf"

I see now (even though then the trim should start with 1 and not 2). I think the confusion, besides my own fault, may come from this sentence:

"trim it and record its "parent node" (could be in reverse hierarchy) in the code."

I do understand now what the reverse hierarchy was intended to mean, but why not avoid altogether the parent/child (which is only relevant for the formatting) and just use the word "neighbor" like in the wikipedia (like here we end up trimming first 1 which is actually the parent of the 5 when we root the tree, and record the child...).

Maybe the confusion is only on my side and you don't need to change anything.

Very interesting puzzle btw :thumbsup:, will definitely upvote it once I finish it.
Thanks for feedback, I modified the wording. It was confusing since I was not clear when I wrote it.

I see what you mean. But then, Input section should state just "a list of numbers" instead of "a list of N numbers", as there are not necessarily N numbers.

I would still suggest to use another variable to denote the length of the list of numbers, and the stub generator parsing improvement as stated above. But it's ok if you think otherwise.

Thanks again.

I get what you mean now. I delete the N and put an example.
Thanks!

Goal
* Please add the following as one of the notes:

The nodes are labelled with natural numbers starting from 1 and increasing consecutively. For example, a tree with 5 nodes will have nodes 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.

Constraints
* Please delete the constraint.

Stub generator
* Please change "CODE" to "pruferCode" for consistency with Goal and Input sections.

Thanks.
